content: Thank you so much for this puzzle. I enjoyed it greatly, even though I've struggled to solve it. I've managed to solve it in the same way icecuber described.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a nice exercise in dynamic programming, with very clear statement and fitting story. I would like it even better with bounds requiring O(n log n) and large weights (1e9 or 1e18), as it has a nice solution (my solution was 31 lines of C++) based on combining two applications of the classic Longest Increasing Subsequence problem. You're welcome to make a sequel with larger constraints.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle

Great puzzle, not sure about the difficulty though, I solved it with brute force and memoization.

The stub generator has issues with several languages : C#, D, Dart, F#, OCml, Pascal, Perl, Python3, Rust, Scala, Swift and VB.Net.

Also a suggestion for a version 2 of this puzzle - perhaps a variant where there is only one solution and the puzzle is worded such that it is an automatic car routing software for Thomas's train station, and the software needs to provide routing instructions to the track switches to direct cars to the correct location to produce the longest possible train; or a balanced set for multiple engines. Could even have multiple switches to control! Could even become a java game with the SDK.

Interesting test cases! I note on a quick scan through that no weights are above 300.
If you can get them under 256 then programmers may be able to use some tricks in their various programming languages.
Slight pity I can't understand your solution provided (any chance you could add a few comments? not required).
At the moment no idea how you actually get an answer of 6 for the 10 cars example
If I can figure out how to do it I will definitely be approving this puzzle.

Thanks.
Let me know if you feel it is really difficult. I may have to re-classify it as Hard.

10
5 9 1 6 8 7 3 10 4 2

This one is easy. One of the final arranged lists will be
10, 9, 8, 7, 4, 2

I guess there is no much value in byte or bit level tricks to gain a nano-second speed advantage. Speed is not an issue. 

A little wider constraint allows rooms for future amendment.
Nice idea. First have to wait and see how well or poorly-received this first one will be.
Thank you notifying me of the issue. Now the stub is updated. Seems to be correct in at least C#.
Perhaps no value as such, but gives programmers options to try different things. Just a suggestion.
